title: How to Make Hungarian Mushroom Soup

steps.headline: Saute the onions and stir in the mushrooms.
steps.description: Carefully chop a few onions in order to get 2 cups (300 g) of chopped onions. You should also heat 2 tablespoons of the chicken or vegetable stock in a saute pan over medium-high heat. Add the chopped onions and 12 ounces (340 g) of sliced mushrooms. Cook the vegetables until they soften. It will take 8 to 10 minutes for the onions and mushrooms to become tender.

steps.headline: Simmer the mixture with stock and seasonings.
steps.description: Stir in 1 teaspoon of the dill weed, 1/2 cup (120 ml) of the chicken or vegetable stock, 1 tablespoon of Hungarian paprika, and 1 tablespoon of soy sauce. Cover the saute pan and turn the heat to medium-low. Let the soup bubble lightly for 15 minutes. Simmering the soup will help the flavors develop, so it's important to cook the soup for the full 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Make a roux.
steps.description: Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Add 3 tablespoons of flour all at once and quickly stir the flour into the melted butter. Keep stirring the roux while you cook it for a couple of minutes. Slowly whisk in 1 cup (240 ml) of milk. Keep whisking until the roux dissolves. The roux will help the soup thicken. If you get lumps in the soup, you can blitz the milk with an immersion blender to break up the lumps.

steps.headline: Cook the roux with the vegetable mixture.
steps.description: Slowly stir the vegetable and onion mixture into the pot with the thickened milk. You should also stir in the remaining 1/2 cup (120 ml) of the chicken or vegetable stock. Put the lid on the soup and let the soup simmer gently for 10 to 15 minutes. You can remove the lid and stir the soup every once in a while to keep it from sticking to the bottom of the pan.

steps.headline: Season and serve the classic Hungarian mushroom soup.
steps.description: Remove the lid and stir in 1 teaspoon of salt, freshly ground black pepper (to taste), 2 teaspoons of lemon juice, and 1⁄2 cup (115 g) of sour cream. Taste the soup and adjust the seasonings according to your preferences. You can stir in the remaining teaspoon of dill weed for a stronger flavor. Garnish the soup with the 1/4 cup (5 g) of chopped fresh parsley.

steps.headline: Wash and cut the vegetables.
steps.description: Peel 2 medium white onions, chop them and set them aside. Wash and peel 2 medium carrots and use a sharp knife to carefully dice them. You should also wash 1 green or red bell pepper. Cut away the stem and remove the core. Wash out any seeds in the center of the pepper and chop it. Keep the chopped onions in a separate prep bowl since they'll need to cook before you add the carrots and pepper.

steps.headline: Saute the onions, carrots, bell pepper, garlic and paprika.
steps.description: Heat 1/4 cup (60 ml) of olive oil in a large pot over medium-high heat. Add the chopped onions and cook them for a few minutes so they soften. Add the diced carrots, chopped pepper, 1 large clove of minced garlic, and 1 tablespoon of Hungarian paprika. Continue to cook the vegetables for another minute. The vegetables won't become completely tender. They'll finish cooking as they simmer in the water and chicken stock.

steps.headline: Stir in the mushrooms, barley, stock, and water.
steps.description: Add 1 1/2 pounds (190 g) of fresh sliced mushrooms, 1/2 ounce (14 g) of dried mushrooms, 1/2 teaspoon of dried thyme, 1/2 cup (100 g) of pearl barley, 6 cups (1.4 liters) of chicken stock and 4 cups (945 ml) of water. Try using crimini mushrooms for the fresh mushrooms and cèpes or porcini for the dried mushrooms.

steps.headline: Simmer the soup until the barley is tender.
steps.description: Turn the heat up to high so the soup comes to a boil. Stir the soup and reduce the heat down to medium-low so that it bubbles gently. Simmer the soup with the lid uncovered for 50 to 60 minutes. The barley should be tender. Add salt and pepper to taste. If you're worried that too much of the soup is evaporating as it simmers, reduce the temperature so that the soup doesn't bubble as much or place the lid on the pot as it simmers.

steps.headline: Mix a cornstarch slurry and stir it into the soup.
steps.description: Measure out 2 teaspoons of cornstarch and place it in a small prep bowl. Stir in 1/4 cup (60 ml) of lemon juice until the cornstarch dissolves. Slowly pour the cornstarch slurry into the soup as you stir. The cornstarch will help the soup thicken as it finishes cooking. You can substitute cold water for the lemon juice. Just avoid using hot water which could make the slurry lumpy.

steps.headline: Finish cooking the soup.
steps.description: Turn the heat up so the soup returns to a boil. Stir the soup well so the cornstarch slurry is incorporated. Let the soup boil for a couple of minutes as you stir. It should thicken a little once it's ready to serve. Serve the Hungarian mushroom barley soup with 1/4 cup (5 g) of snipped fresh dill for garnish.
